sp.p: O! he will make thee eternally enamourd of him there: doe Sirrah; doe: 'twill allay your fellowes Fury a little.

sp.speaker: 1. Pyrgus.

l.hi: Maſter, mocke on: the ſcorne thou giueſt me,

sp.l: Pray Ioue ſome Lady may returne on thee:

sp.speaker: 2. Pyrgus,
sp.p: No: you ſhall ſee me doe the Moore: Maſter, lend me your ſcarfe a little.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Here, 'tis at thy ſeruice, Boy:

sp.speaker: 2. Pyrgus.
sp.p: You, Maſter Minos, harke hither a little. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: How do'ſt like him? art not rapt? art not tickled now? do'ſt not applaud, Raſcall? do'ſt not applaud?

sp.speaker: Hiſtrio.
sp.p: Yes: what will you aske for 'hem a weeke, Captaine?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: No you mangonizing ſlaue, I will not part from 'hem: you'll ſell 'hem for Enghles you; let's ha' good cheare to morrow night at ſupper, Stalker, and then wee'll talke, good Capon, & Plouer, do you hear, Sirrah? & do not bring your eating Plaier with you there; I cannot away with him: He will eate a legge of mutton, while I am in my porridge, the leane Poluphagus, his belly is like Barathrum, he lookes like a Midwife in Mans apparrell, the ſlaue; nor the villanous-out-of-tune Fidler O Enobarbus, bring not him. What haſt thou there? ſix and thirty? ha?

sp.speaker: Hiſt.
sp.p:
No, here's all I haue (Captaine) ſome fiue and twenty. 'Pray Sir, will you preſent, & accommodate it vnto the Gentleman:
for mine owne part, I am a meere ſtranger to his Humour: beſides, I haue ſome buſineſſe inuites me hence, with Maſter Aſinius Lupus, the Tribune.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Well: goe thy waies; purſue thy Proiects, let me alone with this Deſſeigne: my Poëtaſter ſhall make thee a Play, & thou ſhalt be a man of good parts, in it. But ſtay, let me ſee: Doe not bring your Father AEſope, your Polititian; vnleſſe you can ramme vp his mouth with Cloues: the ſlaue ſmells ranker then ſome ſixteene Dung-hilles, and is ſeuenteene times more rotten: Mary, you may bring Friskin, my Zany: Hee's a good skipping Swaggerer; and your fat Foole there, my Mango, bring him too: but let him not begge Rapiers, nor ſcarfes in his ouer-familiar playing face, nor roare out his barren bold Ieſtes, with a tormenting Laughter, betweene drunke and dry. Doe you heare, Raſcall? Giue him warning, Admonition, to forſake his ſawcy glauering Grace, and his goggle Eye: it does not become him, Sirrah: tell him ſo.

sp.speaker: Hiſtrio.
sp.p: Yes Captaine: Iupiter, and the reſt of the Gods confine your moderne delights, without diſguſt.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Stay: thou ſhalt ſee the Moore, ere thou goeſt: what's he, with the halfe Armes there, that ſalutes vs out of his cloake, like a Motion? ha?

sp.speaker: Hiſtrio.
sp.p: O Sir, his dubblet's a little decayed; he is otherwiſe a very ſimple honeſt fellow, Sir: one Demetrius, a dreſſer of Playes about the towne, here; we haue hir'd him to abuſe Horace, and bring him in, in a Play, with all his Gallants: as, Tibullus, Mecoenas, Cornelius Gallus, and the reſt.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: And: why ſo, Stinkard?

sp.speaker: Hiſtrio.
sp.p: O, it will get vs a huge deale of money (Captaine) and we haue neede on't; for this Winter ha's made vs all poorer, then ſo many ſtaru'd Snakes: No body comes at vs; not a Gentleman, nor a—

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: But, you know nothing by him; doe you, to make a Play of?

sp.speaker: Hiſtrio.
sp.p:
Faith, not much, Captaine: but our Author will
deuiſe inough:

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Why, my Parnaſſus, here, ſhall helpe him, if thou wilt: Can thy Author doe it impudently enough?

sp.speaker: Hiſt.
sp.p: O, I warrant you, Captaine: and ſpitefully inough too; he ha's one of the moſt ouerflowing villanous wits, in Rome. He will ſlander any man that breathes; If he diſguſt him.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: I'le know the poore, egregious, nitty Raſcall, and he haue ſuch commendable Qualities, I'le cheriſh him: ſtay; here comes the Tartar; I'le make a gathering for him; I: a Purſe, and put the poore ſlaue in freſh ragges; tell him ſo, to comfort him: well ſaid Boy.

sp.speaker: 2. Pyrg.
sp.l: Where art thou Boy? where is Calipolis?

l.hi: Fight earth quakes, in the entrailes of the earth,
And Easterne whirle-windes in the helliſh ſhades:
Some foule contagion of th'infected heauens
Blast all the trees; and in their curſed tops
The diſmall night-rauen and tragicke Owle
Breed, and become fore-runners of my fall.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Well, now fare thee well, my honeſt Penny-biter: Commend me to ſeuen Shares and a halfe: and remember to morrow: if you lacke a ſeruice, you ſhall play in my name, Raſcalls; but you ſhall buy your owne cloth: and I'le ha' two ſhares for my Countenance: let thy Author ſtay with me.

sp.speaker: Demetr.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: 'Twas well done little Minos: thou didſt ſtalke well: for-giue me that I ſaid thou ſtunkſt, Minos: 'twas the ſauour of a Poet, I met ſweating in the ſtreete, hanges yet in my noſtrills:

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Who? Horace?

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: I; he, do'ſt thou know him?

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: O, he forſooke me moſt barbarouſly, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Hang him fuſty Satyre; he ſmells all Goate; he carries a Ram, vnder his Arme-holes, the ſlaue: I am the worſe when I ſee him. Did not Minos impart?

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Yes, here's twenty Drachmes, he did conuey.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Well ſaid, keepe 'hem, weell ſhare anon; come little Minos.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Faith Captaine, I'le be bould to ſhew you a Miſtres of mine, a Iewellers Wife, a Gallant, as we goe along.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: There ſpoke my Genius. Minos, ſome of thy Eringoes, little Minos; ſend: come hither Parnaſſus. I muſt ha thee familiar with my little Locuſt, here; tis a good Vermine they ſay. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: BVT ſweete Lady, ſay: am I well inough attir'd for the Court, in ſadneſſe?

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: Well inough? excellent well, ſweete

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: This ſtraight-bodied Citty attire (I can tell you) will ſtirre a Courtiers blood, more, then the fineſt looſe Sackes the Ladies vſe to be put in; and then you are as well Iewelld as any of them; your Ruffe, and linnen about you, is much more pure then theirs: And for your beauty, I can tell you, there's many of them would defie the Painter, if they could change with you. Marry, the worſt is, you muſt looke to be enuied, and endure a few Court-frumps for it.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: O God! Madam, I ſhall buy them too cheape: Giue me my Muffe, and my Dogge there. And will the Ladies be any thing familiar with me, thinke you?

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p:
O Hercules! Why, you ſhall ſee 'hem flocke about you with their puffe wings, and aske you, where you bought your Lawne? and what you paid for it? Who ſtarches
you? and entreat you to helpe 'hem to ſome pure Landreſſes, out of the City.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: O, Cupid! Giue me my Fanne, and my Maſque too: And wil the Lords, and the Poets there, vſe one well too, Lady?

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: Doubt not of that: you ſhall haue kiſſes from them, goe pit-pat, pit-pat, pit-pat, vpon your Lips, as thicke as ſtones out of ſlings, at the aſſault of a Citty. And then your 〈…〉 the 〈◊〉 of 〈…〉 that you cannot 〈…〉 your head (if you would) in three Winters after.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: Thanke you, ſweete Lady. O Heauen! And how muſt one behaue her ſelfe amongſt 'hem? you know all.

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: Faith, impudently inough, Miſtreſſe Chloë, & well inough. Cary not too much vnder-thought betwixt your ſelfe and them; nor your Citty mannerly word (forſooth) vſe it not too often in any Caſe; but plaine I, Madam; and No, Madam: Nor neuer ſay, your Lordſhip, nor your Honor; but, you, and you my Lord, and my Lady: the other, they count too ſimple, and minſitiue. And though they deſire to kiſſe Heauen with their Titles, yet they will count them fooles that giue them too humbly.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: O intollerable Iupiter! By my troth Lady, I would not for a world, but you had lyen in my houſe: and i'faith you ſhall not pay a farthing, for your boord; nor your Chambers.

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: O ſweete Miſtreſſe Chloë!

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: I faith, you ſhall not Lady; nay good Lady, doe not offer it.

sp.speaker: Cor. Gallus.
sp.p: Come, where be theſe Ladies? By your leaue, bright Starres; this Gentleman and I are come to man you to Court: where your late kind Entertainment is now to be requited with a Heauenly Banquet.

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: A Heauenly Banquet, Gallus?

sp.speaker: Cor. Gallus.
sp.p: No leſſe, my deare, Cytheris.

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.p: That were not ſtrange, Lady, if the Epithete were onely giuen for the Company inuited thither; your ſelfe, and this faire Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: Are we inuited to Court, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p: You are Lady, by the great Princeſſe Iulia; who longs to greet you with any fauours, that may worthily make you an often Courtier.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: In ſincerity, I thanke her, Sir. You haue a Coach? ha' you not?

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p: The Princeſſe hath ſent her owne, Lady.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: O Venus! that's well: I doe long to ride in a Coach moſt vehemently:

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: But ſweete Gallus, pray you, reſolue me, why you giue that heauenly praiſe, to this earthly Banquet?

sp.speaker: Cor. Gallus.
sp.p: Becauſe (Cytheris) it muſt be celebrated by the heauenly powers: All the Gods, and Goddeſſes will be there; to two of which, you two muſt be exalted.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: A pretty fiction in truth.

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: A fiction indeed Chloë, and fit, for the fit of a Poet.

sp.speaker: Cor. Gallus.
sp.p: Why, Cytheris, may not Poets (from whoſe diuine ſpirits, all the honors of the Gods haue beene deduc't) intreat ſo much honor of the Gods, to haue their diuine preſence at a Poëticall Banquet?

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: Suppoſe that no fiction: yet, where are your Habilities to make vs two Goddeſſes, at your Feaſt?

sp.speaker: Cor. Gallus.
sp.p: Who knowes not (Cytheris) that the ſacred breath of a true Poet, can blow any vertuous Humanity, vp to Deity?

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p:
To tell you the femall truth (which is the ſimple truth) Ladies; and to ſhew that Poets (in ſpight of the world) are able to Deify them ſelues: At this Banquet, to which you are inuited, we intend to aſſume the figures of the Gods; and to giue our ſeuerall Loues the Formes of Goddeſſes. Ouid, will be Iupiter: the Princeſſe Iulia, Iuno: Gallus here Apollo; you Cytheris,
Pallas: I will be Bacchus, and my Loue Plautia, Ceres. And to inſtall you, and your Husband, faire Chloë, in honors, equall with ours; you ſhall be a Goddeſſe, and your Husband a God.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: A God? ô my God!

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.p: A God; but a lame God, Lady: for he ſhall be Vulcan, and you Venus. And this will make our Banquet no leſſe then heauenly.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: In ſincerity, it will be ſugred. Good Ioue, what a pretty fooliſh thing it is to be a Poet! But harke you, ſweete Cytheris; could they not poſſibly leaue out my Husband? me thinkes a Bodies Husband do's not ſo well at Court; A bodies Friend, or ſo: But Husband, 'tis like your Clog to your Marmaſet, for all the world, and the heauens.

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: Tut; neuer feare, Chloë: your Husband will be left without in the Lobby, or the great Chamber; when you ſhall be put in, i'the Cloſet, by this Lord, and by that Lady.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: Nay, then I am certified: he ſhall goe.

div.head: SCENA TERTIA.
div.stage: Horace, Albius, Criſpinus, Tucca, Demetrius, Gallus, Tibullus, Cytheris, Chloë.

sp.speaker: Gallus.
sp.p: Horace! Welcom.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Gentlemen, heare you the newes?

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.p: What newes, my Quintus?

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.l: Our melancholike Friend, Propertius,
Hath cloſ'd him ſelfe, vp, in his Cynthias Tombe;
And will by no intreaties be drawne thence.

sp.speaker: Albius.
sp.p: May, good Maſter Criſpinus; Pray you bring neere the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Criſpinus? Hide me, good Gallus; Tibullus ſhelter me.

sp.speaker: Criſpinus.
sp.p: Make your approach, ſweete Captaine.

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.p: What meanes this, Horace?

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: I am ſurpriz'd againe; Farewell.

sp.speaker: Gallus.
sp.p: Stay, Horace.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: What, and be tir'd on, by yond' Vulture? No: Phoebus defend me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.l: 'Slight! I hold my life,
This ſame is he met him in Via ſacra.

sp.speaker: Gallus.
sp.p: Troth, 'tis like enough. This Act of Propertius reliſheth very ſtrange, with me.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: By thy leaue, my neat Scoundrell: what, is this the mad Boy you talk't on?

sp.speaker: Criſpiaus.
sp.p: I: this is Maſter Albius, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Giue me thy hand, Agamemnon; we heare abroad, thou art the Hector of Citizens: what ſayeſt thou? are we welcome to thee, noble Pyrrhus?

sp.speaker: Albius.
sp.p: Welcome, Captaine? by Ioue and all the Gods i'the Capitoll.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: No more, we conceaue thee. Which of theſe is thy Wedlocke, Menelaus? thy Hellen? thy Lucrece? that we may doe her honor; mad Bay?

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: She i'the little veluet Cap, Sir; is my Miſtres.

sp.speaker: Albius.
sp.p: For fault of a better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: A better, prophane Raſcall? I cry thee mercy (my good Scroile) was't thou?

sp.speaker: Albius.
sp.p: No harme, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Shee is a Venus, a Vesta, a Melpomene: Come hither Penelope; what's thy name, Iris?

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: My name is Chloë, Sir; I am a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Thou art in merit to be an Empreſſe (Chloë) for an Eye, and a Lip; thou haſt an Emperors Noſe: kiſſe me againe: 'tis a vertuous Punque, So. Before Ioue, the Gods were a ſort of Goſlinges, when they ſuffred ſo ſweete a breath, to perfume the bed of a ſtinkard: thou hadſt ill fortune, Thisbe; the Fates were infatuate; they were, Punque; they were.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: That's ſure, Sir; let me craue your Name, I pray you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: I am know'n by the Name of Captaine Tucca, Punque: the noble Romane, Punque: a Gent'man, and a Commaunder, Punque.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: In good time: a Gentleman, and a Commaunder? that's as good as a Poet?

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: A prety inſtrument: It's my Coſen Cytheris Viole, this: iſt not?

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: Nay, play Coſen; it wants but ſuch a voice, and hand, to grace it, as yours is.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Alas Coſen, you are merily inſpir'd.

sp.speaker: Cytheris.
sp.p: 'Pray you play, if you loue me.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Yes coſin: you knowe, I doe not hate you.

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p: A moſt ſubtil wench! How ſhe hath bayted him with a Viole yonder, for a ſonge!

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Coſin, 'pray you call Miſtreſſe Chloë; ſhe ſhall heare an Eſſay of my Poetry.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: I'le call her. Come hither Cocatrice: here's one, will ſet thee vp, my ſweet Punque; ſet thee vp.

sp.speaker: Chl.
sp.p: Are you a Puet, ſo ſoone, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Wife: mum.

lg.head: CANTVS.

l.hi: LOVE is blinde, and a want on;
In the whole worlde, there is ſcant •
• one ſuch another:

lg.l: No, not his Mother.
He hath pluckt her Doues, and Sparrowes,

l.hi: To fether his ſharpe Arrowes,
And alone preuaileth,

lg.l: Whilst ſicke Venus waileth.
But if Cypris once recouer
The wag; it ſhall behoue her

l.hi: To looke better to him:
Or ſhe will vndoe him.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: O, moſt odoriferous Muſicke!

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p:
A, ha; Stinkard. Another Orpheus, you ſlaue, another
Orpheus; an Arion, riding on the backe of a Dolphin, Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Haue you a Copie of this Dittie, Sir?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Maſter Albius ha's.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I, but in trueth, they are my Wiues Verſes; I muſt not ſhewe 'hem.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Shewe 'hem Bankerupt, ſhew 'hem; they haue ſalt in 'hem, and will brooke the ayre, Stinkard.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: How? to his bright miſtreſſe, Canidia?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: I, ſir, that's but a borrowed name; as Ouids Corinna, or Propertius his Cynthia, or your Nemeſis, or Delia, Tibullus.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: It's the name of Horace his Witch, as I remember.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: VVhy? the Ditt'is all borrowed; 'tis Horaces: hang him Plagiary.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: How? he borrowe of Horace? he ſhall pawne himſelfe to ten Brokers, firſt. Doe you heare, Poëtaſters? I knowe you to be Knightes, and men of worſhippe. Hee ſhall write with Horace, for a Talent: and let Mecoenas and his whole Colledge of Critickes take his part: thou ſhalt do't young Phoebus: thou ſhalt, Phaeton; thou ſhalt.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Alas, ſir, Horace? he is a meere ſpunge; nothing but Humours and Obſeruation; he goes vp and down ſucking from euery ſocietie; and when he comes home, ſqueazes himſelfe dry againe. I knowe him, I.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Thou ſayeſt true, my poore Poeticall Furie, he will pen all he knowes. A ſharpe thorny-tooth'd Satyricall Raſcall, flye him; He carries Haye in his horne; he will ſooner looſe his beſt friend, then his leaſt Ieaſt. VVhat he once drops vpon paper, againſt a man, liues eternally to vpbraide him in the mouth of euery ſlaue Tankerd-bearer, or Water-man: not a Baud, or a boy that comes from the bake houſe, but ſhall point at him: 'tis all Dogge, and Scorpion; hee carries poyſon in his teeth, and a ſting in his taile; fough. Bodie of Ioue! I'le haue the ſlaue whipt one of theſe daies for his Satyres, and his Humours, by one caſheer'd Clarke, or another.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: We'll vndertake him, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: I, and tickle him i'faith, for his Arrogancie, and his impudence, in commending his owne thinges: and for his trā ſlating: I can trace him i'faith: ô, he is the moſt open fellowe, liuing; I had as lieue as a newe Suite, I were at it.

sp.speaker: Fuc.
sp.p: Say no more then, but doe it: 'tis the onely way to get thee a newe ſuite: ſting him, my little Neufts; I'le giue you inſtructions: I'le be your Intelligencer, wee'll all ioyne, and hange vpon him like ſo many horſeleaches: the Players and all. Wee ſhall ſuppe togither ſoone; and then weele conſpire, i'-faith.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: O, that Horace had ſtayed ſtill, here.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: So would not I: for both theſe would haue turn'd Pythagoreans then.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: What, mute?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I, as fiſhes i'faith: come Ladies, ſhall wee goe?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: VVee await you, ſir. But Miſtreſſe Chloë aſkes, if you haue not a God to ſpare, for this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: VVho, Captaine Tucca?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: I; hee.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Yes, if wee can inuite him along, he ſhall be Mars.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: Ha's Mars any thing to doe with Venus?

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p: O, moſt of all, Ladie.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: Nay, then I pray' let him be inuited: and what ſhall Crispinus be?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Mercury, Miſtreſſe Chloë.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: Mercury? that's a Poet? is't?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: No Ladie; but ſomewhat enclyning that way: hee is a Herald at Armes.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: A Herald at Armes? good: and Mercury? pretty: he ha's to doe with Venus too?

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p: A little, with her face, Ladie; or ſo.

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: 'Tis verie well; pray' let's goe, I long to bee at it.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Gentlemen, ſhall wee pray your companies along?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: You ſhall not onely pray, but preuaile, Ladie. Come, ſweete Captaine.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Yes, I follow; but thou muſt not talke of this now, my little Bankeroupt.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Captaine, looke here: mum.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: I'le goe write, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Doe, doe: ſtay; there's a Drachme, to purchaſe Ginger-bread, for thy Muſe.

div.head: SCENA QVARTA.
div.stage: Lupus, Hiſtrio, Lictor, Minos, Mecoenas, Horace.

sp.speaker: Lup.
sp.p: Come, let vs talke here; here wee may be priuate: ſhut the dore, Lictor. You are a Player, you ſay.

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: I, and't pleaſe your worſhippe.

sp.speaker: Lup.
sp.p: Good: and how are you able to giue this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Hiſt.
sp.p: Mary Sir, they directed a Letter to mee, and my fellow Sharers.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: Speake lower; you are not now i'your Theater, Stager my ſword Knaue. They directed a letter to you, and your fellow-Sharers: forward.

sp.speaker: Hiſt.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; to hyre ſome of our Properties; as a Scepter, and a Crowne, for Ioue; and a Caduceus, for Mercury: and a Petaſus—

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: Caduceus? and Petaſus? Let mee ſee your Letter. This is a Coniuration; a Conſpiracy, this. Quickly, on with my Buſkins: I'le act a Tragedy, i'faith. Will nothing but our Gods, ſerue theſe Poets to prophane? dispatch. Player, I thanke thee. The Emperour ſhal take knowledge of thy good ſeruice. Who's there now? Looke knaue. A Crowne, and a Scepter? this is good: Rebellion, now?

sp.speaker: Lictor.
sp.p: 'Tis your Pothecary, ſir, Maſter Minos.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p:
VVhat tell'ſt thou mee of Pothecaries, Knaue? Tell
him, I haue affaires of State, in hand; I can talke to no Pothecaries, now. _____ Heart of mee! Stay the Pothecary there.

You ſhall ſee, I haue fiſh't out a cunning piece of Plot now; They haue had ſome intelligēce, that their Proiect is diſcouer'd, and now haue they dealt with my Pothecary, to poyſon mee; tis ſo; knowing, that I meant to take Phyſick to day: As ſure as Death, 'tis there. Iupiter, I thanke thee, that thou haſt yet made mee ſo much of a Polititian. You are welcome, ſir; Take the potiō frō him there; I haue an Antidote more then you wote of, Sir; Throw it on the ground there: So. Now fetch in the Dogge; And yet wee cannot tarry to try Experiments, now: Arreſt him, you ſhall goe with mee, ſir; I'le tickle you Pothecary; I'le giue you a Glyſter, i'faith. Haue I the Letter? I: 'tis here. Come, your Faſces, Lictors: The halfe pikes, & the Halberds, take them downe from the Lares, there; Player, aſſiſt mee.

sp.speaker: Mecae.
sp.p: Whether now, Aſinius Lupus, with this Armory?

sp.speaker: Lup.
sp.p: I cannot talke now; I charge you aſſiſt mee: Treaſon, Treaſon,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: How? Treaſon?

sp.speaker: Lup.
sp.p: I: if you loue the Emperour, and the State, followe me.

div.head: SCENA QVINTA.
div.stage: Ouid, Iulia, Gallus, Cytheris, Tibullus, Plautia, Albius, Chloë, Tucca, Criſpinus Hermogenes, Pyrgus.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Gods, and goddeſſes, take your ſeuerall ſeates. Now, Mercury, mooue your Caduceus, and in Iupiters name commaunde ſilence.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: In the name of Iupiter; Silence.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: The Crier of the Court hath too clarified a voice.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.p: Peace Momus.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p:
Oh, he is the god of Reprehenſion; let him alone. 'Tis
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
his office. Mercury, goe forward; and proclaime after Phoebus, our high pleaſure, to all the Deities that ſhall partake this high Banquet.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: The great God, Iupiter,
Of his licentious goodneſſe,
VVilling to make this Feaſt, no Faſt
From any manner of Pleaſure;
Nor to bind any God or Goddeſſe,
To be any thing the more God, or Goddeſſe, for their names:
He giues them all free Licence,
To ſpeak no wiſer, then perſōs of baſer Titles;
And to be nothing better, then cōmon Men, or VVomen.
And therefore no God
Shal need to keep himſelf more ſtrictly to his Goddeſſe,
Then any man do's to his wife.
Nor any Goddeſſe
Shall need to keepe herſelfe more ſtrictly to her God,
Then any woman do's to her Huſband.
But, ſince it is no part of wiſdome,
In theſe daies, to come into Bonds;
It ſhall be lawfull for euery Louer,
To breake louing oathes,
To change their Louers, & make loue to others,
As the heate of euery ones Bloode,
And the ſpirit of our Nectar ſhall inſpire.
And Iupiter ſaue Iupiter.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: The great, &c.
Of his, &c.
VVilling, &c.
From any, &c.
Nor to, &c.
To bee, &c.
He giues, &c.
To ſpeak, &c.
And to, &c.
And ther. &c.
Shal need, &c.
Then any, &c.
Nor any, &c.
Shall need, &c.
Then any, &c.
But, ſince, &c.
In theſe.
It ſhall, &c.
To breake, &c.
To chāge, &c.
As the, &c.
And the, &c.
And Iupi. &c.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: So: now we may play the Fooles, by Authoritie.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: To play the foole by Authoritie, is wiſdome.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Away with your Mattery Sentences, Momus; they are to graue, and wiſe, for this meeting.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Mercury, giue our Ieaſter a ſtoole, let him ſit by; and reach him of our Cates.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p:
Do'ſt heare, Mad Iupiter? VVe'll haue it enacted; He, that ſpeaks the firſt wiſe word, ſhall be made Cuckold. VVhat ſayſt
thou? Is't not a good Motion?

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Deities, are you all agreed?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Agreed, great Iupiter.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I haue read in a Booke, that to play the Foole wiſely, is high wiſdome.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How now, Vulcan! will you be the firſt Wizard?

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Take his wife, Mars; & make him Cuckold, quickly.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Come, Cocatrice.

sp.speaker: Chl.
sp.p: No: let me alone with him, Iupiter: I'le make you take heede, ſir, while you liue againe; if there be twelue in a companie, that you be not the wiſeſt of 'hem.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: No more I will not indeede, wife, hereafter; I'le be here: mum.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Fill vs a bowle of Nectar, Ganymede: we will drinke to our daughter Venus.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Looke to your wife, Vulcan: Iupiter begins to Court her.

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p: Nay, let Mars looke to it: Vulcan muſt do as Venus doe's, beare.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Sirrah, Boy: Catamite. Looke you play Ganymede well now, you ſlaue: Doe not ſpill your Nectar; Carry your Cuppe euen: ſo. You ſhould haue rubd your Face, with whites of Egges, you Raſcall; till your Browes had ſhone like our ſootie brothers here, as ſleeke as a Horne-booke: or ha'ſteept your lips in wine, till you made 'hem ſo Plumpe, that Iuno might haue beene Iealous of 'hem. Punque, kiſſe mee, Punque.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Here daughter Venus, I drinke to thee.

sp.speaker: Chloë
sp.p: 'Thanke you, good Father Iupiter.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Why, Mother Iuno! Gods and Fiends! what, wilt thou ſuffer this ocular Temptation?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Mars is enrag'd; he lookes bigge, and begins to ſtut, for anger.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: VVell plaide, Captaine Mars.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: VVell ſaid, Minſtrell Momus: I muſt put you in? muſt I? When will you be in good fooling of your ſelfe, Fidler? neuer?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: O, 'tis our faſhion, to be ſilent, when there is a better Foole in place, euer.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: 'Thanke you, Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Fill to our daughter Venus, Ganymede; who fils her father with affection.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: VVilt thou be raunging, Iupiter, before my face?

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: VVhy not, Iuno? why ſhould Iupiter, ſtand in awe of thy Face, Iuno?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Becauſe it is thy wiues Face, Iupiter.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: What, ſhall a Huſband be afraid of his wiues Face? will ſhee paint it ſo horribly? Wee are a King, Cotqueane; and wee will raigne in our pleaſures; & we will cudgell thee to death, if thou finde fault with vs.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I will finde fault with thee, King Cuckold-maker: what, ſhall the King of Gods turne the King of Good fellowes, and haue no Fellow in wickedneſſe? This makes our Poëts, that knowe our Prophaneneſſe, liue as prophane, as wee: By my God-head, Iupiter; I will ioyne with all the other Gods, here; binde thee hand and foote; throwe thee downe into earth; and make a poore Poët of thee, if thou abuſe me thus.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: A good ſmart-tongu'd Goddeſſe; a right Iuno.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Iuno, wee will cudgell thee, Iuno: wee tolde thee ſo yeſterday, when thou wert iealous of vs, for Thetis.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Nay, to day ſhe had me in Inquiſition too.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: VVell ſaide, my fine Phrygian Fry, informe, informe. Giue mee ſome wine, King of Heralds; I may drinke to my Cocatrice.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: No more, Ganymede; wee will cudgell thee, Iuuo: By Styx, we will.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I'ts well; Gods may growe impudent in Iniquitie, and they muſt not be tolde of it.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Yea, wee will knocke our Chinne againſt our Breſt; and ſhake thee out of Olimpus, into an Oyſter-boate, for thy ſcoulding.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Your Noſe is not long enough to doe it, Iupiter; if all thy Strumpets, thou haſt among the Starres tooke thy part. And there is neuer a Star in thy Forehead, but ſhal be a Horne, if thou perſiſt to abuſe mee,

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: A good Ieaſt, I faith.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: We tell thee, thou angerſt vs, Cotqueane; and we will thunder thee in peeces, for thy Cotqueanity: we will lay this City deſolate, and flat as this hand, for thy offences. Theſe two fingers are the Walls of it; theſe within, the People; which People, ſhall be all throwne downe thus, and nothing left ſtanding in this Citty, but theſe walls.

sp.speaker: Criſpinus.
sp.p: Another good Ieſt.

sp.speaker: Albius.
sp.p: O, my hammers, and my Cyclops! this Boy fils not wine enough, to make vs kind enough, to one another;

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Nor thou haſt not collied thy face enough, Stinkard.

sp.speaker: Albius.
sp.p: I'le ply the table with Nectar, and make them friends.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Heauen is like to haue but a lame Skinker, then.

sp.speaker: Albius.
sp.p: "Wine, and good Liuers, make true louers: I'le ſentence them togither. Here Father: here Mother: for ſhame, drinke your ſelues drunke, and forget this diſſention: you two ſhould cling togither, before our faces, and giue vs example of Vnity.

sp.speaker: Gallus.
sp.p: O, excellently ſpoken, Vulcan, on the ſodaine!

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p: Iupiter, may doe well to preferre his Tongue to ſome office, for his Eloquence.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: His Tongue ſhall be Gent'man Vſher to his Wit, and ſtill goe before it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: An excellent fit office.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: I, and an excellent good ieaſt, beſides:

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: What, haue you hired Mercury, to cry your ieaſtes you make?

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Momus, you are enuious:

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Why, you whoreſon block-head, 'tis your only blocke of witte in faſhion (now adaies) to applaud other folkes ieaſtes.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: True: with thoſe that are not Artificers them ſelues. Vulcan, you nod; and the mirth of the feaſt droopes.

sp.speaker: Pyrgus.
sp.p: He ha's fild Nectar ſo long, till his braine ſwimmes in it.

sp.speaker: Gallus.
sp.p:
What, doe we nod, fellow Gods? ſound Muſicke,
and let vs ſtartle our ſpirits with a ſong.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Doe, Apollo: thou art a good Muſitian.

sp.speaker: Gallus.
sp.p: What ſaies Iupiter?

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Ha? ha?

sp.speaker: Gallus.
sp.p: A Song.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: Why, doe, doe, ſing:

sp.speaker: Plautia.
sp.p: Bacchus, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Plautia.
sp.p: But, to this ſong?

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.p: Sing, for my part.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Your belly weighes downe your head, Bacehus: here's a ſong toward.

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.p: Begin, Vulcan.

sp.speaker: Albius.
sp.p: What elſe? what elſe?

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Say, Iupiter.

sp.speaker: Criſpinus.
sp.p: I, ſay, ſay.

l.hi: VVAKE; our mirth beginnes to die:
Quicken it with tunes, and wine:
Raiſe your notes; you're out: fie, fie;
This Drouzineſſe is an ill ſigne.
We baniſh him the Queere of Gods,
That droopes agen:
Then all are men,
For here's not one, but nods.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: I like not this ſodaine and generall heauineſſe, amongſt our Godheads: 'Tis ſomewhat ominous. Apollo, Command vs lowder Muſicke, and let Mercury, and Momus contend to pleaſe, and reuiue our ſenſes.

l.hi: THEN, in a free and lofty ſtrayne,
Our broken tunes we thus repaire;
And we anſwere them againe,
Running diuiſion on the panting Ayre:

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: To celebrate this Feast of Senſe,

l.hi: As free from Scandall, as Offenſe.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Here is Beauty, for the Eye;

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: For the Eare, ſweete Melody;

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ambroſiack Odours, for the ſmell;

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Delicious Nectar, for the Taste;

sp.speaker: Ambo
sp.l: For the Touch, a Ladies Waſte;

l.hi: Which doth all the reſt excell.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.p: I: This hath wak't vs. Mercury, our Herald; Goe from our ſelfe the great God Iupiter, to the great Emperour, Augustus Caeſar: And command him, from vs (of whoſe Bounty he hath receaued his Sir-name, Augustus) that for a Thankeoffring to our Beneficence, he preſently Sacrifice as a Diſh to this Banquet, his beautifull and wanton Daughter Iulia: She's a curſt Queane, tell him; and plaies the ſcould behind his backe: Therefore let her be Sacrific'd. Commaund him this, Mercury, in our high name of Iupiter Altitonans.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Stay, Feather-footed Mercury; and tell Auguſtus, from vs, the great Iuno Saturnia; if he thinke it hard to doe, as Iupiter hath commanded him, and Sacrifice his Daughter, that he had better to doe ſo tenne times, then ſuffer her to loue the well-noſ'd Poet, Ouid; whom he ſhall doe well to whip, or cauſe to be whipt, about the Capitoll, for ſoothing her, in her Follies.

div.head: SCENA SEXTA.
div.stage: Caeſar, Mecoenas, Horace, Lupus, Histrio, Minos, Lictors, Ouid, Gallus, Tibullus, Tucca, Criſpinus, Albius, Hermogenes, Pyrgus, Iulia, Cytheris, Plautia, Chloë.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: What ſight is this? Mecoenas, Horace, ſay;
Haue we our ſenſes? Doe we heare? and ſee?
Or, are theſe but Imaginary obiects
Drawne by our Phantaſie? Why, ſpeake you not?
Let vs doe Sacrifice? Are they the Gods?
Reuerence: Amaze: and Fury fight in me.
What? Doe they kneele? Nay, then I ſee tis true
I thought impoſſible: ô impious ſight!
Let me diuert mine eyes; the very thought
Euerts my Soule, with Paſſion: Looke not Man.
There is a Panther, whoſe vnnaturall eyes
Will ſtrike thee dead: turne then; and dye on her
With her owne death.

sp.speaker: Mecoenas.
sp.p: Horace. What meanes imperiall Caeſar?

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: What, would you haue me let the Strumpet liue, That, for this Pageaunt, earnes ſo many deathes?

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Boy, ſlinke Boy.

sp.speaker: Pyrgus.
sp.p: 'Pray Iupiter, we be not follow'd by the ſent, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Say, Sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Albius.
sp.p: I play Vulcan, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: But, what are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Albius.
sp.p: Your Citizen, and Ieweller, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: And what are you, Dame?

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: I play Venus, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: I aske not, what you play? but, what you are?

sp.speaker: Chloë.
sp.p: Your Citizen, and Iewellers wife, Sir:

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: And you, good Sir?

sp.speaker: Criſpinus.
sp.p: Your Geutleman, parcell-Poet, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: O, that prophaned Name!
And are theſe ſeemely company for thee,
Degenerate Monſter? all the reſt I know;
And hate all knowledge, for their hatefull ſakes.
Are you, that firſt the Deities inſpir'd
With skill of their high Natures, and their Powers,
The firſt Abuſers of their vſe-full light;
Prophaning thus their Dignities, in their formes;
And making them like you, but counterfeites?
O, who ſhall follow Vertue, and embrace her,
When her falſe boſome is found nought but Aire?
And yet, of thoſe embraces, Centaures ſpring,
That warre with humane Peace, and poyſon Men.
Who ſhall, with greater comforts, comprehend
Her vnſeene being, and her excellence;
When you, that teach, and ſhould eternize her,
Liue, as ſhe were no Law vnto your liues:
Nor liu'd her ſelfe, but with your idle breathes?
If you thinke Gods but fain'd, and Vertue painted,
Know, we ſuſtaine an actuall reſidence;
And, with the Title of an Emperour,
Retaine his ſpirit, and imperiall power:
By which (in impoſition too remiſſe,
Licentious Naſo, for thy violent wronge,
In ſoothing the declin'd Affections
Of my baſe Daughter,) I exile thy feete
From all approach, to our imperiall Court,
On paine of death: and thy miſgotten Loue
Commit to patronage of Iron doores;
Since her ſoft-harted Sire cannot containe her.

sp.speaker: Mecoenas.
sp.p: O, good my Lord; forgiue: be like the Gods:

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Let royall Bounty (Caeſar) mediate.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: There is no Bounty to be ſhewed to ſuch,
As haue no reall goodnes: Bountie is
A ſpice of Vertue: and what vertuous Act
Can take effect on them, that haue no power
Of equall habitude to apprehend it;
But liue in worſhip of that Idole Vice.
As if there were no Vertue, but in ſhade
Of ſtronge imagination, meerely enforc't?
This ſhewes, their Knowledge is meere Ignorance;
Their farre fetcht Dignity of ſoule, a Fancy;
And all their ſquare pretext of Grauity
A meere vaine Glory: hence: away with 'hem.
I will preferre for knowledge, none, but ſuch
As rule their liues by it, and can becalme
All Sea of Humour, with the marble trident
Of their ſtrong ſpirits: Others fight below
With Gnats, and ſhadowes; Others nothing know. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENA SEPTIMA.
div.stage: Tucca, Criſpinus, Pyrgus, Horace, Mecoenas, Lupus, Histrio.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: What's become of my little Punque, Venus; and the poult-foote Stinkard, her Husband? ha?

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: O, they are rid home i'the Coach, as faſt as the wheeles can runne.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: God Iupiter is baniſht, I heare: and his Cockatrice, Iuno, lockt vp: 'Hart; and and all the Poetry in Parnaſſus get me to be a Player againe, I'le fell 'hem my ſhare for ſix pence. But this is Humours; Horace, that Goat-footed enuious Slaue: hee's turn'd fawne now; an Informer, the Rogue: 'tis he has betraid vs all; Did you not ſee him, with the Emperour, crouching?

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p:
Well, follow me. Thou ſhalt libell, and I'le cudgell
the Raſcall. Boy, pronide me a Trunchion; Reuenge ſhall gratulate him, Tam Marti, quam Mercurio.

sp.speaker: Pyrgus.
sp.p: I, but Maſter; take heed how you giue this out, Horace is a Man of the Sword.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: 'Tis true, introth: they ſay, hee's valiant.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Valiant? ſo is mine Arſe: Gods, and Fiendes? I'le blow him into aire, when I meete him next: He dares not fight with a puck-fiſt.

sp.speaker: Pyrgus.
sp.p: Maſter, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Where? Iupiter ſaue thee, my good Poet; my Prophet; my Noble Horace. I ſcorne to beate the Rogue i'the Court; and I ſaluted him, thus faire, bicauſe he ſhould ſuſpect nothing, the Raſcall; Come; wee'll goe ſee how forward our Iourneyman is toward the vntruſſing of him.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Doe you heare, Captaine? I'le write nothing in it but Innocence: becauſe I may ſweare I am Innocent. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Nay, why purſue you not the Emperour for your reward, now; Lupus?

sp.speaker: Mecoenas.
sp.l: Stay, Aſinius; you, and your Stager, and your band of Lictors:
I hope your ſeruice merits more reſpect,
Then thus, without a thankes, to be ſent hence?

sp.speaker: Histrio.
sp.l: Well, well, ieaſt on, ieaſt on.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.l: Thou baſe vnworthy Groome. (Lupus.) I 'tis good.
Was this the Treaſon? this, the dangerous plot,
Thy clamorous tongue ſo bellowed through the Court?
Hadſt thou no other Proiect to encreaſe
Thy Grace with Caeſar, but this Wooluiſh traine;
To pray vpon the life of innocent Mirth,
And harmeleſſe pleaſures, bred, of noble wit?
Away: I loath thy preſence: Such as thou,
They are the Moathes, and Scarabbes of a State;
The Bane of Kingdomes; and the dregges of Courts:
Who (to endeer themſelues to any 'mploiement)
Care not, whoſe fame they blaſt; whoſe life they endanger:
And vnder a diſguiſ'd, and cobweb Maſque
Of loue, vnto their Soueraigne, vomit foorth
Their owne prodigious malice; and pretending
To be the Props, and Columnes of his ſafety,
The Guardes vnto his Perſon, and his Peace,
Diſturbe it moſt, with their falſe Lapwing cries.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.l: Good. Caeſar ſhall know of this; beleeue it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mecoenas.
sp.l: Caeſar doth know it (Wolfe) and to his knowledge,
He will (I hope) reward your baſe Endeuours.
"Princes that will but heare, or giue acceſſe
"To ſuch officious Spies, can nere be ſafe:
"They take in poyſon, with an open Eare,
"And free from Danger, become ſlaues to Feare. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.l: Baniſht the Court? Let me be baniſht life;
Since the chiefe end of Life is there concluded:
Within the Court, is all the Kingdome bounded;
And as her ſacred Spheare doth comprehend
Ten thouſand times ſo much, as ſo much Place
In any part of all the Empire elſe;
So euery Body, moouing in her Spheare,
Containes ten thouſand times aſmuch in him,
As any other, her choice Orbe excludes.
As in a circle, a Magitian, then
Is ſafe, againſt the Spirit, he excites;
But out of it, is ſubiect to his rage,
And looſeth all the vertue of his Art:
So I, exil'd the circle of the Court,
Looſe all the good gifts, that in it I ioy'd.
"No Vertue currant is, but with her ſtamp:
"Nor no Vice vitious, blaunch't with her white hand.
The Court's the Abſtract of all Romes deſert;
And my deare Inlia, the Abſtract of the Court.
Mee thinkes, now I come neare her, I reſpire
Some aire, of that late comfort, I receau'd:
And while the Euening, with her modeſt vaile,
Giues leaue to ſuch poore Shadowes as my ſelfe,
To ſteale abroad; I, like a hart-leſſe Ghoſt,
Without the liuing Bodie of my Loue,
Will here walke, and attend her: For I knowe,
Not farre from hence, ſhe is impriſoned,
And hopes, of her ſtrict Guardian, to bribe
So much admittance, as to ſpeake to mee,
And cheere my fainting ſpirits, with her breath.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ouid? my Loue?

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.l: Here, heauenly Iulia.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Here? and not here? O, how that worde doth play
VVith both our Fortunes, differing, like our ſelues,
Both one; and yet diuided, as oppoſ'd?
I High, thou Lowe: ô, this our plight of Place
Doubly preſents the two lets of our Loue,
Locall and ceremoniall Height, and Lowneſſe:
Both waies, I am too high; and thou, too lowe.
Our Mindes are euen, yet: ô, why ſhould our Bodies,
That are their ſlaues, be ſo without their rule?
I'le caſt my ſelfe downe to thee; If I die,
I'le euer liue with thee: no height of Birth,
Of Place, of Dutie, or of cruell Power,
Shall keepe mee from thee; ſhould my Father locke
This bodie vp within a Tombe of Braſſe,
Yet I'le be with thee: If the Formes, I holde
Now in my Soule, be made one ſubſtance with it;
That Soule immortall; and the ſame 'tis now:
Death cannot raze th'affectes, ſhe now retaineth:
And then, may ſhee be any where ſhe will.
The ſoules of Parents rule not Childrens ſoules,
VVhen Death ſets both in their diſſolu'd eſtates:
Then is no Childe, nor Father: then Eternitie
Frees all, from any temporall reſpect.
I come, my Ouid; take me in thine armes:
And let me breath my ſoule into thy breaſt.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.l: O, ſtay my Loue: the hopes thou do'ſt conceiue
Of thy quicke Death, and of thy future Life,
Are not autenticall. Thou chooſeſt Death,
So thou might'ſt ioy thy Loue, in th'other Life.
But knowe (my princely Loue) when thou art dead,
Thou onely muſt ſuruiue in perfect ſoule;
And in the ſoule, are no Affections:
We poure out our Affections with our Bloode;
And with our Bloods affections; fade our Loues.
"No life hath Loue in ſuch ſweete ſtate, as this;
"No Eſſence is ſo deare to moodie Senſe,
"As Fleſh, and Bloode; whoſe Quinteſſence is Senſe.
"Beautie, compoſd of Blood, and Fleſh, moues more,
"And is more plauſible to Blood, and Fleſh:
"Then Spirituall Beautie can be to the Spirit.
Such Apprehenſion, as wee haue in Dreames
(VVhen Sleepe, the bond of Senſes, locks them vp)
Such ſhall we haue, when Death deſtroyes them quite.
If Loue be then thy Obiect, change not life,
Liue high, and happie ſtill: I ſtill belowe,
Cloſe with my Fortunes, in thy height, ſhall ioy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ay me, that Vertue, whoſe braue Eagles winges
VVith euery ſtroake, blowe Starres, in burning Heauen;
Should like a Swallowe (praying toward ſtormes)
Fly cloſe to earth: and with an eager plume
Purſue thoſe Obiectes, which none els can ſee,
But ſeeme to all the world, the emptie Aire.
Thus thou (poore Ouid) and all vertuous men
Muſt pray like Swallowes, on inuiſible foode;
Purſuing Flies, or nothing: and thus Loue,
And euery worldly Fancie, is tranſpoſ'd,
By worldly Tyranny, to what plight it liſt.
O, Father; ſince thou gau'ſt me not my Minde,
Striue not to rule it: Take, but what thou gau'ſt
To thy diſpoſure, thy Affections
Rule not in me; I muſt beare all my griefes,
Let me vſe all my pleaſures: "Vertuous Loue
Was neuer ſcandall to a Goddeſſe ſtate.
But hee's inflexible; and, my deare Loue,
Thy life may chance be ſhortned, by the length
Of my vnwilling ſpeaches to depart.
Farewell, ſweete Life: though thou be yet exil'd,
Th'officious Court, enioy mee amply ſtill:
My Soule, in this my breath, enters thine Eares,
And on this Turrets, Floore, will I lye deade,
Till wee may meete againe; in this proud Height,
I kneele beneath thee in my proſtrate Loue,
And kiſſe the happie ſands, that kiſſe thy feete.
"Great Ioue ſubmits a Scepter, to a Cell;
"And Louers, ere they part, will meete in Hell.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.l: Farewell all companie; and if I could
All light with thee: Helles ſhade ſhould hide my browes,
Till thy deare Beauties beames redeem'd my vowes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ouid; my Loue: alas, may we not ſtay
A little longer (think'ſt thou) vndeſcern'd?

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.l: For thine owne good, faire Goddeſſe, doe not ſtay:
VVho would ingage a Firmament of fires
Shining in thee, for me, a falling Starre?
Be gon, ſweete Life-bloode: if I ſhould deſcerne
Thy ſelfe but toucht, for my ſake, I ſhould die.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I will be gone then; and not Heauen it ſelfe,
Shall drawe me backe.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.l: Yet Iulia, if thou wilt,
A little longer ſtay.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am content.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.l: O mightie Ouid! what the ſway of Heauen
Could not retire, my breath hath turned back.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Who ſhall goe firſt, my Loue? my paſſionate Eyes
VVill not endure to ſee thee turne from mee.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.l: If thou goe firſt, my ſoule will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then wee muſt ſtay.

sp.speaker: Ouid.
sp.l: Aye me; there is no ſtay
In amorous pleaſures: if both ſtay, both die.
I heare thy father; hence my Deitie. Exit Iulia.
Feare forgeth ſoundes in my deluded eares;
I did not heare him: I am mad with Loue.
There is no Spirit, vnder heauen, that workes
VVith ſuch illuſion; yet ſuch witchcraft kill mee,
Ere a ſound minde, without it, ſaue my life.
Here, on my knees, I worſhippe the bleſt Place
That held my Goddeſſe; and the louing Aire,
That cloſ'd her bodie in his ſilken armes:
Vaine Ouid; kneele not to the Place, nor Ayre;
Shee's in thy hart: Riſe then, and worſhippe there.
"The trueſt wiſdome ſillie men can haue,
"Is dotage, on the follies of their fleſh. Exit.

div.head: SCENA PRIMA.
div.stage: Ceſar, Mecoenas, Pallus, Tibullus, Horace, Equites Ro.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: VVE, that haue cōquer'd ſtil, to ſaue the cōquer'd,
And lou'd to make inflictions feard, not felt;
Grieu'd to reprooue, and ioyfull to reward,
More proud of Reconcilement, then Reuenge,
Reſume into the late ſtate of our Loue,
VVorthy Cornelius Gallus, and Tibullus:
You both are Knightes; and you, Cornelius,
A Souldier of Renowne; and the firſt Prouoſt,
That euer let our Romane Eagles fly
On ſwarthy Egypt, quarried with her ſpoyles.
Yet (not to beare colde Formes, nor mens out-termes,
Without the inward fires, and Liues of men)
You both haue Vertues, ſhining through your Shapes;
To ſhewe, your Titles are not writ on Poſtes,
Or hollow Statues, which the beſt men are,
Without Promethean ſtuffings reacht from Heauen.
Sweete Poëſies ſacred Gyrlands crowne your Knighthoodes:
VVhich is, of all the Faculties on Earth,
The moſt abſtract, and perfect; if ſhee be
True borne, and nurſt with all the Sciences;
She can ſo mould Rome, and her Monuments,
Within the liquid Marble of her Lines,
That they ſhall ſtand freſh, and miraculous,
Euen, when they mixe with innouating duſt:
In her ſweete ſtreames ſhall our braue Romane ſpirits
Chace, and ſwimme after Death, with their choyſe deedes
Shining on their white ſhoulders; and therein
Shall Tyber, and our famous Riuers fall
With ſuch attraction, that th'ambitious Line
Of the round World ſhall to her Center ſhrinke,
To heare their Muſicke: And for theſe high Parts,
Ceſar ſhall reuerence the Pierian Artes.

sp.speaker: Mecoe.
sp.l: Your Maieſties high Grace to Poëſie,
Shall ſtand 'gainſt all the dull detractions
Of leaden Soules; who (for the vaine aſſumings
Of ſome, quite worthleſſe of her ſoueraigne wreaths)
Conteine her worthieſt Prophets in contempt.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Happie is Rome of all Earths other States,
To haue ſo true, and great a preſident,
For her inferiour ſpirits to imitate,
As Caeſar is; who addeth to the Sunne,
Influence, and luſtre; in encreaſing thus
His inſpirations, kindling fire in vs.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Phoebus himſelfe ſhall kneele at Caeſars Shrine,
And deck it with Bay Gyrlands deaw'd with VVine,
To quite the worſhip Caeſar does to him:
Where other Princes, hoyſted to their thrones
By Fortunes paſſionate and diſordered power,
Sit in their height, like Clouds, before the Sunne,
Hindring his comforts; and (by their exceſſe
Of cold in Vertue, and croſſe heate in Vice)
Thunder and tempeſt, on thoſe learned heads,
VVhom Caeſar with ſuch Honour doth aduance.

sp.speaker: Tibul.
sp.l: All humane buſineſſe, Fortune doth command
Without all order; and with her blinde hand,
Shee, blinde, beſtowes blinde gifts; that ſtill haue nurſt
They ſee not who, nor how, but ſtill, the worſt.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Caeſar, for his Rule, and for ſo much ſtuffe
As Fortune puts in his hand, ſhall diſpoſe it
(As if his Hand had eyes, and ſoule, in it)
VVith worth and iudgement. "Hands, that part with gifts,
"Or will reſtraine their vſe, without deſert;
"Or with a miſery, numm'd to Vertues right,
"Worke, as they had no Soule to gouerne them,
"And quite reiect her; ſeuering their Eſtates
"From humane order. VVhoſoeuer can,
"And will not cheriſh Vertue, is no man.

sp.speaker: Eques.
sp.l: Virgill is now at hand, imperiall Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Romes Honour is at hand then. Fetch a chaire,
And ſet it on our right hand; where 'tis fit,
Romes Honour, and our owne, ſhould euer ſit.
Now he is come out of Campania,
I doubt not he hath finiſht all his AEneids,
Which, like another Soule, I long t'enioy.
VVhat thinke you three, of Virgill, Gentlemen,
(That are of his profeſſion, though rankt higher)
Or Horace, what ſaiſt thou, that art the pooreſt,
And likelieſt to enuye, or to detract?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Caeſar ſpeakes after common men, in this,
To make a difference of me, for my pooreneſſe:
As if the filth of Pouertie ſunke as deepe
Into a knowing ſpirit, as the Bane
Of riches doth, into an ignorant ſoule.
No Caeſar; they be path-leſſe, mooriſh minds,
That being once made rotten with the dung
Of damned Riches, euer after ſinke
Beneath the ſteppes of any Villany.
But Knowledge is the Nectar, that keepes ſweete
A perfect Soule euen in this Graue of ſinne;
And for my Soule, it is as free, as Caeſars:
For, what I knowe is due, I'le giue to all.
"He that detracts, or enuies vertuous Merit,
"Is ſtill the couetous, and the ignorant ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Thanks Horace, for thy free, and holſome ſharpneſſe:
Which pleaſeth Caeſar more, then ſeruile fawnes.
"A flatterd Prince ſoone turnes the Prince of Fooles.
And for thy ſake, wee'll put no difference more
'Twixt Knights, and Knightly ſpirits, for being poore.
Say then, lou'd Horace, thy true thought of Virgill.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I iudge him of a rectified ſpirit,
By many reuolutions of diſcourſe
(In his bright reaſons influence) refin'd
From all the tartarous Moodes of common Men;
Bearing the Nature, and ſimilitude
Of a right heauenly Bodie; moſt ſeuere
In faſhion, and collection of himſelfe;
And then as cleare, and confident, as Ioue.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: And yet ſo chaſt, and tender is his Eare,
In ſuffering in any Syllable to paſſe,
That, he thinkes, may become the honour'd name
Of Iſſue to his ſo examin'd ſelfe;
That all the laſting fruites of his full merit
In his owne Poemes, he doth ſtill diſtaſte:
As if his mindes Peece, which he ſtroue to paint,
Could not with fleſhly Penſils haue her right.

sp.speaker: Tibul.
sp.l: But, to approue his workes of Soueraigne worth,
This Obſeruation (me thinkes) more then ſerues:
And is not vulgar. That, which hee hath writ,
Is with ſuch iudgement, labour'd, and diſtill'd
Through all the needefull vſes of our liues,
That could a man remember but his Lines,
He ſhould not touch at any ſerious point,
But he might breath his ſpirit out of him.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: You meane, he might repeat part of his workes,
As fit for any conference, he can vſe?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Trew, Royall Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: 'Tis worthily obſeru'd:
And a moſt worthie vertue in his workes.
VVhat thinks, Materiall Horace, of his learning?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: His Learning labours not the Schoole-like Gloſſe,
That moſt conſiſts in Ecchoing VVordes, and Termes,
And ſooneſt wins a man an Empty name;
Nor any long, or far-fetcht Circumſtance,
VVrapt in the curious General'ties of Artes:
But a direct, and Analyticke Summe
Of all the worth and firſt effectes of Artes.
And for his Poëſie, 'tis ſo ramm'd with Life,
That it ſhall gather ſtrength of Life, with being;
And liue hereafter, more admir'd, then now.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: This one conſent, in all your doomes of him,
And mutuall Loues of all your ſeuerall merits,
Argues a truth of merit in you all.

div.head: SCENA SECVNDA.
div.stage: Caeſar, Virgill, Mecoenas, Gallus, Tibullus, Horace, Equites Ro.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: See, here comes Virgill; we will riſe and greet him:
Welcome to Caeſar, Virgill. Caeſar, and Virgill
Shall differ but in ſound; to Caeſar, Virgill
(Of his expreſſed Greatneſſe) ſhall be made
A ſecond Sir-name; and to Virgill, Caeſar.
Where are thy Famous Aeneids? doe vs grace
To let vs ſee, and ſurfet on their ſight.

sp.speaker: Virgill.
sp.l: Worthleſſe they are of Caeſars gracious Eyes,
If they were perfect; much more, with their wants;
Which yet are more, then my Time could ſupply:
And, could great Caeſars expectation
Be ſatisfied with any other ſeruice,
I would not ſhew them.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Virgill is too modeſt;
Or ſeekes, in vaine, to make our longings more.
Shew them, ſweete Virgill.

sp.speaker: Virgill.
sp.l: Then, in ſuch due feare,
As fits Preſenters of great works, to Caeſar,
I humbly ſhew them:

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Let vs now behold
A humane Soule made viſible in life;
And more refulgent in a ſenſeleſſe paper,
Then in the ſenſuall Complement of Kings.
Read, read, thy ſelfe, deare Virgill, let not me
Prophane one accent, with an vntun'd tongue:
"Beſt matter, badly ſhowne, ſhewes worſe, then bad.
See then, this Chayre, of Purpoſe ſet for thee
To reade thy Poeme in: Refuſe it not.
"Vertue, without preſumption, place may take
"Aboue beſt Kings, whom onely ſhe ſhould make.

sp.speaker: Virgill.
sp.l: It will be thought a thing ridiculous
To preſent Eyes, and to all future times
A groſſe vntruth; that any Poet (void
Of Birth, or wealth, or Temporall dignity)
Should, with decorum, tranſcend Caeſars Chayre.
"Poore Vertue raiſ'd, high birth and wealth ſet vnder,
"Croſſeth Heauens courſes, and makes worldlings wonder.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: The courſe of Heauen, and Fate it ſelfe, in this
Will Caeſar croſſe; much more all worldly Cuſtome.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.l: "Cuſtome, in courſe of Honour, euer erres:
"And they are beſt, whom Fortune leaſt preferres.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Horace hath (but more ſtrictly) ſpoke our thoughts.
The vaſt rude ſwinge of generall Confluence
Is, in particular ends, exempt from ſenſe:
And therefore Reaſon (which in right ſhould be
The ſpeciall Rector of all Harmony)
Shall ſhew we are a man, diſtinct by it,
From thoſe that Cuſtome rapteth in her preaſſe.
Aſcend then Virgill: and where firſt by Chaunce
We here haue turnd thy Booke, doe thou firſt read.

sp.speaker: Virgill.
sp.l: Great Caeſar hath his will: I will aſcend.
'Twere ſimple iniury to his free hand,
That ſweeps the Cobwebs, from vnuſed Vertue,
And makes her ſhine proportiond, to her worth,
To be more nice to entertaine his Grace;
Then he is choyſe, and liberall to afford it.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Gentlemen of our Chamber, guard the Doores,
And let none enter. Peace. Beginne, good Virgill.

sp.speaker: Virgill.

l.hi: Meane while,
the Skies gan thunder; and in tayle
Of that, fell powring ſtormes of ſleete, and hayle:

sp.l: The Tyrian Lords, and Troian youth, each where
With Venus Dardane Iulus. Nephew, now, in feare

l.hi: Seeke out for ſeuerall ſhelter through the Plaine;
Whil'ſt Flouds come rowling from the Hills amaine.

sp.l: Dido a Caue, The Troian Aeneas. Prince the ſame
Lighted vpon; There, Earth, and Heauens great Iuno. Dame

l.hi: That hath the charge of Mariage, firſt gaue ſigne
Vnto this Contract; Fier, and Ayre did ſhine,
As guilty of the Match; and from the Hill,

sp.l: The Nymphes, withſhriekings, doe the Region fill.

l.hi: Here first began their Bane; This Day was ground
Of all their Ills: For now, nor Rumours ſound,

sp.l: Nor nice reſpect of State mooues Dido ought;

l.hi: Her Loue, no longer now, by ſtealth is ſought:
She calls this Wedlocke, and with that faire Name
Couers her fault. Forthwith the Bruit, and Fame,

sp.l: Through all the greatest. Lybian Tawnes, is gone;
Fame, a fleete Euill, then which is ſwifter none:

l.hi: That moouing growes, and flying gathers ſtrength;
Little at first, and fearefull; but at length.
She dares attempt the Skies, and ſtalking proud
With feete on Ground, her Head doth pearce a Cloud.

sp.l: This Child, our Parent Earth, ſtird vp with ſpight
Of all the Gods, brought foorth; and, as ſome wright,
She was last ſister of that Giant Coens. Encleadus, &c. Race
That thought to ſcale Ioues Court; right ſwift of Paſe,

l.hi: And ſwifter, far, of Wing. A Monſter vast,
And dreadfull: Looke, how many Plumes are plac't

sp.l: On her huge Corps, ſo many waking Eyes

l.hi: Sticke vnderneath: and (which may ſtranger riſe

sp.l: In the Report) as many Tongues ſhe beares,
As many Mouthes, as many listning Eares.

l.hi: Nightly, in midst of all the Heauen, ſhe flies,
And through the Earths darke ſhadow, ſhrieking, cries;
Nor doe her Eyes once bend, to tast ſweete ſleepe:
By Day, on tops of Houſes, ſhe doth keepe,
Or on high Towers; and doth thence affright
Cities, and Townes of most conſpicuous ſite;
As couetous ſhe is of Tales, and Lies,
As prodigall of Truth: This Monſter, &c.

div.head: SCENA TERTIA.
div.stage: Lupus, Tucca, Criſpinus, Demetrius, Histrio, Lictors, Caeſar, Virgill, Mecoenas, Gallus, Tibullus, Horace, Equites Ro.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: Come, follow me, aſſiſt me, ſecond me: where's the Emperour?

sp.speaker: Eques 1.
sp.p: Sir, you muſt pardon vs.

sp.speaker: Eques 2.
sp.p: Caeſar is priuate now, you may not enter.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Not Enter? Charge 'hem, vpon their Allegeance, Cropſhin.

sp.speaker: Eques 1.
sp.p: We haue a charge to the contrary, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.l: I pronounce you all Traytors, horrible Traytors:
What? Doe you know my Affaires?
I haue Matter of danger, and ſtate, to impart to Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: What, noyſe is there? who's that, names Caeſar?

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: A Friend to Caeſar. One that for Caeſars good would ſpeake with Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Who is't? looke, Cornelius.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: O, bid the turbulent Informer hence;
We haue no vacant Eare, now, to receiue
The vnſeaſond fruits of his officious tongue.

sp.speaker: Mecoenas.
sp.p: You muſt auoid him there.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: I coniure thee; as thou art Caeſar, or reſpect'ſt thine owne ſafety; or the ſafety of the ſtate, Caeſar: Heare me, ſpeake with me, Caeſar: 'tis no common buſines, I come about; but ſuch as, being neglected, may concerne the life of Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: The life of Caeſar? Let him Enter. Virgill, keepe thy Seate.

sp.speaker: Equites.
sp.p: Beare backe there: whether will you? keepe backe.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: By thy leaue good man Vſher: mend thy Periwig, ſo.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: Lay hold on Horace there; and on Mecoenas, Lictors. Romanes, offer no reſcue, vpon your Allegeance: Read royall Caeſar; I'le tickle you, Satyre.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: He will, Humors, he will: He will ſqueeze you, Poet Puckfiſt.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: I'le Lop you off, for an vnprofitable braunch, you Satyricall Varlet.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: I, and Epaminondas your Patron, here, with his flaggon Chayne; Come, reſigne: Though 'twere your great Graund-fathers, the Law ha's made it mine now, Sir. Looke to him, my party-colourd Raſcalls; Looke to him.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: What is this, Aſinius Lupus? I vnderſtand it not.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: Not vnderſtand it? A Libell, Caeſar. A dangerous, ſeditious Libell. A Libell in Picture.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: A Libell?

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: I, I found it in this Horace his ſtudy; in Mecoenas his houſe, here; I challenge the penalty of the Lawes againſt 'hem.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: I, and remember to begge their Land betimes; before ſome of theſe hungry Court-hounds ſent it out.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Shew it to Horace: Aske him, if he know it.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: Know it? His hand is at it, Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Then 'tis no Libell.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: It is the imperfect Body of an Embleme, Caeſar, I began for Mecoenas.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: An Embleme? right: That's Greeke for a Libell. Doe but marke, how Confident he is.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.l: A Iuſt man cannot feare, thou fooliſh Tribune;
Not, though the Malice of traducing Tongues,
The open vaſtneſſe of a Tyrants Eare,
The ſenſeleſſe Rigor of the wreſted Lawes,
Or the red Eyes of ſtrain'd Authority
Should, in a point, meete all to take his life:
His Innocence is Armour 'gainſt all theſe.

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: Innocence? ô Impudence! Let me ſee, Let me ſee. Is not here an Eagle? And is not that Eagle meant by Caeſar? ha? Do's not Caeſar giue the Eagle? Anſwere me; what ſayſt thou?

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Haſt thou any Euaſion, Stinkard?

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: Now hee's turn'd dumbe. I'le tickle you, Satyre.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Piſh. Ha, ha:

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: Doſt thou piſh me? Giue me my Long ſword.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: With reuerence to great Caeſar, worthy Romanes, Obſerue but this ridiculous Commenter:
sp.l: The Soule to my Deuiſe, was in this Diſtich.

l.hi: Thus, oft, the baſe and rauenous multitude
Suruiue, to ſhare the ſpoyles of Fortitude:

sp.l: Which in this Body, I haue figur'd here;
A VVLTVRE—

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: A Vulture? I; now, 'tis a Vulture. O, abhominable! Monſtrous! Monſtrous! ha's not your Vulture a Beake? ha's it not Legges? and Tallons? and Wings? and Fethers?

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Touch him, old Buskins.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: And therefore muſt it be an Eagle?

sp.speaker: Mecoenas.
sp.p: Reſpect him not, good Horace: Say your Deuiſe.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: A VVLTVRE and a WOLFE—

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: A Wolfe? Good. That's I; I am the Wolfe: My name's Lupus; I am meant by the Wolfe. On, on; A Vulture, and a Wolfe—

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: Praying vpon the Carcaſſe of an ASSE—

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: An Aſſe? Good ſtill: That's I, too. I am the Aſſe. You meane me by the Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Mecoenas.
sp.p: 'Pray thee, leaue braying then.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: If you will needs take it, I cannot with Modeſtie giue it from you.

sp.speaker: Mecoenas.
sp.l: But, by that Beaſt, the old Aegyptians
Were wont to Figure in their Hieroglyphicks,
Patience, Frugality, and Fortitude;
For none of which, we can ſuſpect you, Tribune.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Who was it, Lupus, that inform'd you firſt, This ſhould be meant by vs? or was't your Comment?

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: No, Caeſar: A Player gaue me the firſt light of it, indeede.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: I, an honeſt Sycophant-like Slaue, and a Politician, beſides.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Where is that Player?

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: He is without, here.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Call him in.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Call in the Player, there; Maſter Aeſope, call him.

sp.speaker: Equites.
sp.p: Player? where is the Player? Beare backe; None, but the Player, enter.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Yes: this Gent'man, and his Achates muſt.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: 'Pray you, Maſter Vſher; wee'll ſtand cloſe, here.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: 'Tis a Gent'man of Qualitie, this; though he be ſomewhat out of Clothes, I tell yee. Come Aeſope: haſt a Bay leafe i'thy mouth? Well ſaid; be not out, Stinkard. Thou ſhalt haue a Monopoly of playing, confirm'd to thee and thy Couey, vnder the Emperours broad Seale, for this ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Is this he?

sp.speaker: Lupus.
sp.p: I, Caeſar: this is he.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Let him be whipt. Lictors, Goe, take him hence.
And Lupus, for your fierce Credulity,
One fit him with a paire of larger Eares:
'Tis Caeſars Doome, and muſt not be reuok't.
VVe hate, to haue our Court, and Peace diſturb'd
VVith theſe quotidian Clamours. See it done.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Gag him, we may haue his ſilence.

sp.speaker: Virgill.
sp.l: Caeſar hath done like Caeſar. Fayre, and Iuſt
Is his Award, againſt theſe braineleſſe Creatures.
'Tis not the wholſome ſharpe Morality,
Or modeſt anger of a Satyricke Spirit,
That hurts, or wounds the body of a State;
But the ſiniſter Application
Of the malitious, ignorant, and baſe
Interpreter; who will diſtort, and ſtraine
The generall Scope and purpoſe of an Author,
To his particular, and priuate ſpleene.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: VVe knowe it, our deare Virgill; and eſteeme it
A moſt diſhoneſt practiſe, in that man,
Will ſeeme too wittie in anothers worke.
What would Cornelius Gallus, and Tibullus?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Nay, but as thou art a man, do'ſt heare? a man of worſhippe; and honorable: Hold, here, take thy chaine againe: Reſume, mad Mecoenas. What? do'ſt thou thinke, I meant t'haue kept it, old Boy? No; I did it but to fright thee, I: to try how thou would'ſt take it. What? will I turne Sharke, vpon my Friends? or my friends Friends? I ſcorn it with my three Soules. Come; I loue Bully Horace, as well as thou do'ſt, I: 'tis an honeſt Hieroglyphick. Giue me thy wriſt Helicon. Do'ſt thou thinke, I'le ſecond ere a Rhinoceros of them all, againſt thee? ha? or thy noble Hippocrene, here? I'le turne Stager firſt, and be whipt too; do'ſt thou ſee, Bully?

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: You haue your will of Caeſar; vſe it Romanes.
Virgill ſhall be your Praetor; and our ſelfe
VVill here fit by, Spectator of your ſports;
And thinke it no impeach of Royalty.
Our Eare is now too much prophan'd ((Graue Maro)
VVith theſe diſtaſts, to take thy ſacred Lines:
Put vp thy Booke, till both the Time and wee
Be fitted with more hallowed circumſtance
For the receiuing ſo diuine a Labour.
Proceede with your deſſeigne.

sp.speaker: Mecoe.
sp.p: Gall. Tib. Thanks to great Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Tibullus, drawe you the Inditement then, whil'ſt Horace arreſts them, on the Statute of Calumny: Mecoenas, and I will take our places here; Lictors, aſſiſt him.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: I am the worſt Accuſer, vnder Heauen.

sp.speaker: Gallus.
sp.p: Tut, you muſt do't: 'Twill be noble Mirth.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: I take no knowledge, that they doe maligne me.

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.p: I, but the world takes knowledge.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: 'Would the World knew How hartily I wiſh, A Foole ſhould hate me.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Body of Iupiter! What? Will they arraigne my briske Poëtaſter, and his poore Iourneyman, ha? Would I were abroad skeldring for Twopence, ſo I were out of this Labyrinth againe: I doe feele my ſelfe turne Stinkard already. But I muſt ſet the beſt Face I haue, vpon't now: well ſaid, my diuine, deft Horace; bring the whorſon detracting Slaues to the Barre, doe; Make 'hem hold vp their ſpread Golls; I'le giue in Euidence for thee, if thou wilt. Take courage Criſpinus; Would thy man had a cleane band.

sp.speaker: Criſpinus.
sp.p: What muſt we doe, Captaine?

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt ſee anon: Doe not make Diuiſion with thy Legges, ſo.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: What's he, Horace?

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.p: I only know him for a Motion, Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: I am one of thy Commanders, Caeſar; A man of Seruice, and Action; My Name is Pantilius Tucca: I haue ſeru'd i'thy Warres againſt Marke Antony; I.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Doe you know him, Cornelius?

sp.speaker: Gallus
sp.p: Hee's one, that hath had the Muſtring, or Conuoy of a Company, now, and then; I neuer noted him by any other Imployment.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: We will obſerue him better.

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.p: Lictor, proclaime Silence, in the Court.

sp.speaker: Lictor.
sp.p: In the name of Caeſar, Silence.

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.p: Let the Parties, the Accuſer, and the Accuſed, preſent them ſelues.

sp.speaker: Lictor.
sp.p: The Accuſer, and the Accuſed; Preſent your ſelues in Court.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Demet. Here.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Reade the Inditement.

sp.speaker: Tibul.
sp.p: Rufus Laberius Criſpinus, and Demetrius Fannius, hold vp your hands. You are, before this time, toyntly and ſeuerally indited; and here preſently to be arraigned, vpon the Statute of Calumny, or Lex Remmia (The one by the name of Rufus Laberius Criſpinus, aliàs Criſpinas, Poētaſter, and Plagiary: the other by the name of Demetrius Fannius, Play-dreſſer & Plagiary) That you (not hauing the feare of Phoebus or his ſhafts, before your eyes) contrary to the peace of our liege Lord, Auguſtus Caeſar, his Crowne and dignitie, and againſt the forme of a Statute in that caſe made, and prouided; haue moſt ignorantly, fooliſhly, and (more like your ſelues) malitiouſly gone about to depraue, and calumniate the Perſon and writings of Quintus Horatius Flaccus, here preſent, Poet, and Prieſt to the Muſes: and to that end haue mutually conspir'd, and plotted, at ſundry times, as by ſeuerall meanes, and in ſundry places, for the better accompliſhing your baſe and Enuious purpoſe; taxing him, falſely, of Sefe loue, Arrogancy, Impudence, Rayling, filching by Tranſlation, &c. Of all which Calumnies, and euery of them in manner and forme aforeſaid, what anſwere you? Are you Guiltie, or not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Not Guilty, ſay.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Dem. Not Guilty.

sp.speaker: Tibullus.
sp.p: How will you be tryed?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: By the Romane Gods, and the nobleſt Romanes.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Dem. By the Romane Gods, and the nobleſt Romans.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Here fits Mecoenas, and Cornelius Gallus;
Are you contented to be tryed by theſe?

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: I; So the noble Captaine may be ioyn'd with them in Commiſſion; ſay.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Dem. I; ſo the noble Captaine may bee ioyn'd with them in Commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Virgill.
sp.p: VVhat ſaies the Plaintife.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I am content.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Captaine, then take your Place.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p:
Alas, my worſhipfull Praetor! 'tis more of thy Gent'neſſe, then of my deſeruing, Iwuſſe. But, ſince it hath pleaſ'd
the Court to make choyce of my VViſdome, and Grauitie, Come my Calumnious Varlets; Let's heare you talke for your ſelues now, an howre or two. What can you ſay? Make a noyſe. Act, Act.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Stay; turne, & take an Oath firſt. Youſhall ſweare,
By Thunder-darting Ioue, the King of Gods;
And by the Genius of Auguſtus Caeſar;

l.hi: By your owne white, and vncorrupted Soules;

sp.l: And the deepe reuerence of our Romane Iustice;

l.hi: To iudge this Caſe, with Truth and Equitie:
As bound, by your Religion, and your Lawes.

sp.l: Now reade the Euidence: But firſt demaund
Of either Priſoner, if that Writ be theirs.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Shew this vnto Criſpinus. Is it yours?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Say I. what? doſt thou ſtand vpon it, Pimpe? Doe not deny thine owne Minerua; thy Pallas; the Iſſue of thy Braine.

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: Yes, it is mine.

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p: Shewe that vnto Demetrius. Is it yours?

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: There's a Father, will not deny his owne Baſtard, now, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Reade them alowd.

sp.speaker: Tibul.
sp.l: Rampe vp, my Genius; be not Retrograde:

l.hi: But boldly nominate a Spade, a Spade.

sp.l: VVhat, ſhall thy Lubricall and glibbery Muſe
Liue, as ſhe were defunct, like Punque in Stewes?

l.hi: Alas! That, were no moderne Conſequence,

sp.l: To haue cothurnall Buſkins frighted hence.
No; teach thy Incubus to Poetize,

l.hi: And throwe abroad thy ſpurious Snotteries,
Vpon that puft-vp Lumpe of Barmy froth,
Or Clumſy Chil-blain'd Iudgement; that, with Oath,
Magnificates his Merit; and beſpaules
The conſcious Time, with humorous Fome; & brawles,

sp.l: As if his Organons of Senſe would crack

l.hi: The ſinewes of my Patience. Breake his Back,

sp.l: O Poëts all and ſome: For now wee liſt

l.hi: Of strenuous Venge-ance to clutch the fiſt.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: I mary, this was written like a Hercules in Poetry, now.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Excellently well threatned.

sp.speaker: Virgill.
sp.p: I, and as ſtrangely worded, Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: We obſerue it.

sp.speaker: Virgill.
sp.p: The other, now.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: This's a fellow of a good prodigall tongue too; this'll doe well.

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.l: Our Muſe is in minde for th'vntruſſing a Poet:

l.hi: I ſlip by his Name; for moſt men doe know it:

sp.l: A Critick, that al the world beſcumbers
With Satyricall Humors, and Lyricall Numbers:

l.hi: And for the moſt part, himſelfe doth aduance

sp.l: VVith much ſelfe-loue, and more Arrogance:

l.hi: And (but that I would not be thought a Prater)
I could tell you, he were a Tranſlater.

sp.l: I knowe the Authors from whence he ha's ſtole,

l.hi: And could trace him too, but that I vnderſtand 'hem not full and whole.

sp.stage: (Tucca. That line is broke looſe from all his fellowes; chainehim vp ſhorter, doe.)

l.hi: The beſt note I can giue you to knowe him by,

sp.l: Is, that he keepes Gallants company;

l.hi: Whome I would wiſh, in time ſhould him feare,
Leaſt after they buy Repentance too deare.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Well ſaid. This carries Palme with it.

sp.speaker: Horace.
sp.l: And why, thou Motley Gull? why ſhould they feare?
When haſt thou knowne vs wrong, or taxe a Friend?
I dare thy malice, to betray it. Speake.
Now thou curlſt vp, thou poore and naſty Snake;
And ſhrinkſt thy poyſnous head into thy Boſome:
Out Viper; thou that eat'ſt thy Parents, hence.
Rather, ſuch ſpeckled Creatures, as thy ſelfe,
Should be eſchew'd, and ſhund: ſuch, as will bite
And gnaw their abſent Friends, not cure their Fame;
Catch at the looſeſt Laughters, and affect
To be thought Ieſters; ſuch, as can deuiſe
Things neuer ſeene, or heard, t' impayre mens Names,
And gratifie their credulous Aduerſaries;
Will carry Tales; doe baſeſt offices;
Cheriſh diuided Fiers; and increaſe
New Flames, out of old Embers; will reueale
Each ſecret that's committed to their Truſt:
Theſe be blacke Slaues; Romanes, take heede of theſe.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.l: Thou twangſt right, little Horace; they be indeed:
A couple of Chap-falne Curres. Come, Wee of the Bench,
Let's riſe to the Vrne, and condemne 'hem, quickly.

sp.speaker: Virgill.
sp.l: Before you goe together (worthy Romanes)
We are to tender our Opinion;
And giue you thoſe Inſtructions, that may adde
Vnto your euen Iudgement in the Cauſe;
Which thus we doe Commence: Firſt, you muſt know
That where there is a true, andperfect Merit,
There can be no Deiection; and the Scorne
Of humble Baſeneſſe, oftentimes, ſo workes
In a high Soule vpon the groſſer Spirit;
That to his bleared, and offended Senſe,
There ſeemes a hideous Fault blaz'd in the Obiect;
When only the Diſeaſe is in his Eyes.
Here-hence it comes, our Horace now ſtands taxt
Of Impudence, Selfe-loue, and Arrogance,
By theſe, who ſhare no merit in themſelues;
And therefore, thinke his Portion is as ſmall.
For they, from their owne guilt, aſſure their Soules,
If they ſhould confidently praiſe their workes,
In them it would appeare Inflation;
Which, in a full, and well-digeſted man,
Cannot receiue that foule abuſiue name,
But the faire Title of Erection.
And, for his trewe vſe of tranſlating Men,
It ſtill hath beene a worke of as much Palme
In cleareſt Iudgements, as t' inuent, or make.
His ſharpneſſe, that is moſt excuſable;
As being forc't out of a ſuffering Vertue,
Oppreſſed with the Licence of the Time:
And howſoeuer Fooles, or Ierking Pedants,
Players, or ſuch like Buffonary wits,
May with their beggerly, and barren traſh,
Tickle baſe vulgar eares, in their deſpight;
This (like Ioues Thunder) ſhall their pride controule.
"The honest Satyre hath the happiest Soule.
Now, Romanes, you haue heard our thoughts. Withdrawe, when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Tibul.
sp.p: Remoue the Accuſed from the Barre.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Who holdes the Vrne to vs? ha? Feare nothing: I'le quitte you, mine honeſt pittifull Stinkards. I'le do't.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Captaine, you ſhall eternally girt me to you, as I am Generous.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Goe to.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Tibullus, let there bee a caſe of Vizardes priuately prouided: wee haue founde a Subiect to beſtowe them on.

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p: It ſhall be done, Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p:
Here be wordes, Horace, able to baſtinado a mans
Eares.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I. Pleaſe it great Caeſar, I haue Pils about mee
(Mixt with the whiteſt kinde of Ellebore)
Would giue him a light vomite; that ſhould purge
His Braine, and Stomack of thoſe tumorous heates:
Might I haue leaue to miniſter vnto him.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: O! be as Aeſculapius, Gentle Horace;
You ſhall haue leaue, and he ſhall be your Patient.
Virgill, vſe your Authoritie, commaund him forth.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Caeſar is carefull of your health, Crispinus;
And hath himſelfe choſe a Phiſtian
To miniſter vnto you: take his Pils.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: They are ſomewhat bitter, but wholſome;
Take another, yet; ſo: Stand by, they'll worke anone.

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.l: Romanes, returne to your ſeuerall ſeates: Lictors,
Bring forward the Vrne; and ſet the Accuſed at the Barre.

sp.speaker: Tucca.
sp.p: Quickly, you VVhorſon Egregious Varlettes; Come forwarde. What? ſhall wee ſit all day vpon you? you make no more haſte, now, than a Begger vpon Pattins: or a Phiſitian to a Patient that ha's no money, you Pilchers.

sp.speaker: Tibull.
sp.p: Rufus Laberius Criſpinus, and Demetrius Fannius, holde vp your handes.
